paper_title.ja: Marking and identification of nucleolar chromosomes in Allium grayitetraploids by Ag-NOR staining and fluorescence in situhybridization
paper_title.en: Marking and identification of nucleolar chromosomes in Allium grayi tetraploids by Ag-NOR staining and fluorescence in situ hybridization :

description.ja: Allium grayi Regel collected in Harbin, Heilongjiang Province, China, in Tonghae. Kangwondo, Republic of Korea and in Ohyamazaki Town. Kyoto Pref., Japan, were karyologically investigated. All the plants in Harbin and Tonghae showed the common chromosome number of 2n=4x=32, whereas the plants in Ohyamazaki showed the chromosome number of 2n=4x=32 and of 2n=5x=40. Karyotypes of the Tonghae and Ohyamazaki tetraploid plants and the majority of Harbin pants of the species were cornmonly, 2n=32=26m+5sm+1st, whereas those of a few plants in Harbin were 2n=32=26m+6sm. Ag-NOR staining and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) detected that four among the six nucleolar chromosomes were median-centromeric and two were submedian-centromeric chromosomes.
description.en: Allium grayi Regel collected in Harbin, Heilongjiang Province, China, in Tonghae. Kangwondo, Republic of Korea and in Ohyamazaki Town. Kyoto Pref., Japan, were karyologically investigated. All the plants in Harbin and Tonghae showed the common chromosome number of 2n=4x=32, whereas the plants in Ohyamazaki showed the chromosome number of 2n=4x=32 and of 2n=5x=40. Karyotypes of the Tonghae and Ohyamazaki tetraploid plants and the majority of Harbin pants of the species were cornmonly, 2n=32=26m+5sm+1st, whereas those of a few plants in Harbin were 2n=32=26m+6sm. Ag-NOR staining and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) detected that four among the six nucleolar chromosomes were median-centromeric and two were submedian-centromeric chromosomes.

paper_title.ja: Polyploidy distribution and karyotype variation in the several wild populations of ┣DBAllium grayi(/)-┫DB Regel(Liliaceae)in Okayama Prefecture, Japan
paper_title.en: Polyploidy distribution and karyotype variation in several wild populations of Allium grayi Regel (Liliaceae) in Okayama prefecture, Japan

description.en: Polyploidy distribution and Variations of karyotypes in Allium grayi Regel were examinedin 7 natural populations in Okayama Prefecture, Japan. They showed often tetraploid (2n=32) and pentaploid (2n=40) plants together in the 5 populations and hexaploid (2n=48) plants in the Kasaoka population. The hexaploid plant of the species was found for the first time in western-half part of Japan. Tetraploid plants were solely observed in the Oku population and only pentaploid plants were found in the Kuse population. The analysis revealed the presence of the 2 major different karyotypes: One type consisted of only median- and submedian-centromeric chromosomes and the other type consisted of subterminal-centromeric chromosome(s) in addition to median- and submedian-centromeric chromosomes.

paper_title.en: Polyploidy distribution and karyotype variation in several wild populations of Allium grayi Regel (Liliaceae) in Okayama prefecture, Japan

description.en: Polyploidy distribution and Variations of karyotypes in Allium grayi Regel were examinedin 7 natural populations in Okayama Prefecture, Japan. They showed often tetraploid (2n=32) and pentaploid (2n=40) plants together in the 5 populations and hexaploid (2n=48) plants in the Kasaoka population. The hexaploid plant of the species was found for the first time in western-half part of Japan. Tetraploid plants were solely observed in the Oku population and only pentaploid plants were found in the Kuse population. The analysis revealed the presence of the 2 major different karyotypes: One type consisted of only median- and submedian-centromeric chromosomes and the other type consisted of subterminal-centromeric chromosome(s) in addition to median- and submedian-centromeric chromosomes.

paper_title.en: Centromeric transposition of the chromosomes in callus cells of Haplopappus gracilis strain KH-1

description.en: In order to investigate the difference of changeability in chromosome number and structure between two pairs of homologous chromosomes in Haplopappus gracilis callus, karyotype analyses of a number of metaphase chromosome spreads were carried out. More than 90% of cells examined showed chromosome number, 2n=4 as same as normal controls, however the cells with the same karyotype as normal controls decreased to 52.8%, in total. Change rate of centromeric position increased as culture period became long from early to late. Centromeric transposition rate became high in the callus of low growth rate. Change rate of centromeric position of the 2nd chromosomes which have satellites was about 2.5 to 3 times higher than that of the 1st chromosomes in all the concentrations and periods. The 2nd chromosomes of normal controls are subterminal chromosome type, but the majority of changed 2nd chromosome in callus cells was submedian chromosome type. This may probably due to breakage of the long arm of the 2nd chromosome and suggests the existence of breakpoint(s) in the long arm of the 2nd chromosome.

paper_title.en: Centromeric transposition of the chromosomes in callus cells of Haplopappus gracilis strain KH-1

description.en: In order to investigate the difference of changeability in chromosome number and structure between two pairs of homologous chromosomes in Haplopappus gracilis callus, karyotype analyses of a number of metaphase chromosome spreads were carried out. More than 90% of cells examined showed chromosome number, 2n=4 as same as normal controls, however the cells with the same karyotype as normal controls decreased to 52.8%, in total. Change rate of centromeric position increased as culture period became long from early to late. Centromeric transposition rate became high in the callus of low growth rate. Change rate of centromeric position of the 2nd chromosomes which have satellites was about 2.5 to 3 times higher than that of the 1st chromosomes in all the concentrations and periods. The 2nd chromosomes of normal controls are subterminal chromosome type, but the majority of changed 2nd chromosome in callus cells was submedian chromosome type. This may probably due to breakage of the long arm of the 2nd chromosome and suggests the existence of breakpoint(s) in the long arm of the 2nd chromosome.

paper_title.ja: Application of genomic in situ hybridization to the chromosome complement of the intergeneric hybrid between Leucanthemella linearis (Matum. ) Tzuvelev and Nipponanthemum nipponicum (Franch. et Maxim. ) Kitamura

Application of genomic in situ hybridization to the chromosome complement of the intergeneric hybrid between Leucanthemella linearis (Matsum.) Tzuvelev and Nipponanthemum nipponicum (Franch. et Maxim.) Kitamura :
paper_title.en: Application of genomic in situ hybridization to the chromosome complement of the intergeneric hybrid between Leucanthemella linearis (Matum. ) Tzuvelev and Nipponanthemum nipponicum (Franch. et Maxim. ) Kitamura

description.ja: Leucanthemella linearis (2n=18) and Nipponanthemum nipponicum (2n=18) were readily crossed by hand pollination. Root tips of their F_1 hybrid were harvested, pretreated and fixed by the conventional technique before they were macerated with an enzymatic solution of 2% cellulase Onozuka RS, 1% pectolyase Y-23, 75 mM KCl and 7.5 mM EDTA at pH 4.0 for 30 min at 37℃. They were squashed with 45% acetic acid. Total genomic DNA was extracted from fresh leaves of L. linearis and N. nipponicum separately by the improved CTAB method. These DNA probes were labelled with biotin-14-dATP by the nick translation method. Combined denaturation of the genomic DNA probes and the slide preparation were conducted by an automatic temperature controller at 85℃ for 10 min and they were hybridized at 37℃ for 12-14 h. By genomic in situ hybridization, total genomic DNA probe of N. nipponicum was hybridized to nine small chromosomes of N. nipponicum yellow-FITC-fluoresced in the chromosome set at mitotic metaphase in the F_1 hybrid but not to the other nine large chromosomes of L. linearis and these were counterstained red by propidium iodide.
description.en: Leucanthemella linearis (2n=18) and Nipponanthemum nipponicum (2n=18) were readily crossed by hand pollination. Root tips of their F_1 hybrid were harvested, pretreated and fixed by the conventional technique before they were macerated with an enzymatic solution of 2% cellulase Onozuka RS, 1% pectolyase Y-23, 75 mM KCl and 7.5 mM EDTA at pH 4.0 for 30 min at 37℃. They were squashed with 45% acetic acid. Total genomic DNA was extracted from fresh leaves of L. linearis and N. nipponicum separately by the improved CTAB method. These DNA probes were labelled with biotin-14-dATP by the nick translation method. Combined denaturation of the genomic DNA probes and the slide preparation were conducted by an automatic temperature controller at 85℃ for 10 min and they were hybridized at 37℃ for 12-14 h. By genomic in situ hybridization, total genomic DNA probe of N. nipponicum was hybridized to nine small chromosomes of N. nipponicum yellow-FITC-fluoresced in the chromosome set at mitotic metaphase in the F_1 hybrid but not to the other nine large chromosomes of L. linearis and these were counterstained red by propidium iodide.
